column1: Editorial: Why has this interview with Ren Zhengfei gone viral?

On June 10, an exclusive interview with Ren Zhengfei, CEO of Huawei, was published on the front page of the People's Daily. When discussing how to cope with external blockades and suppression, Ren stated, "Don’t dwell on the difficulties—just get things done and move forward step by step." He also called for societal support for theoretical scientific research, which may "take decades or even centuries to see contributions," emphasizing the need for strategic patience with theoretical scientists. As a Chinese entrepreneur, Ren’s words reflect a confidence in "resolutely handling one’s own affairs," a vision that "openness drives further progress," and a determination to adhere to long-term principles by focusing on the frontiers of technological development. His remarks have resonated widely across society.

As is well known, Huawei has long faced sanctions and suppression from the United States and some other Western countries, ranging from chips to 5G technology. Not long ago, Huawei’s Ascend chips were even groundlessly "warned" by the U.S. about usage risks. Yet Huawei has "moved forward step by step," overcoming one difficulty after another. This reflects a growing consensus of values within Chinese society: from the semiconductor sector, which was once a "chokepoint," to the fiercely competitive frontiers of technology such as artificial intelligence and fundamental research, China’s leapfrog progress has never relied on momentary passion but on long-termism—anchoring goals and persevering with sustained effort. It is precisely by insisting on doing "difficult yet right things" that Huawei has gained the resilience to survive direct suppression and blockade, breaking through in "chokepoint" areas like chips and operating systems. "The more open a country is, the more it drives our progress." It should be noted that, in the current environment, the growth and strengthening of private enterprises represented by Huawei rely on the support of China's vast and comprehensive industrial system, infrastructure, talent supply, and institutional safeguards, as well as the country's efforts to build a market-oriented, law-based, and internationalized business environment. Over the past seven years, the central government has held two symposiums for private enterprises to help them overcome difficulties, boost confidence, and outline development blueprints. Last month, the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Promotion of the Private Economy" officially came into effect. With 9 chapters and 78 articles, it continuously optimizes the development environment for the private economy across multiple dimensions such as fairness, regulation, services, and safeguards, setting many "firsts." The principle of "unwaveringly consolidating and developing the public sector and unwaveringly encouraging, supporting, and guiding the development of the non-public sector" has been written into law and repeatedly emphasized in Party documents, providing private enterprises and entrepreneurs with long-term institutional confidence. The resonance between national top-level design and the needs of enterprise development is the most solid support for breaking through blockades and resisting risks.

The increasing emphasis on research and development (R&D) investment across various sectors in recent years reflects a strong societal consensus on "resolutely办好自己的事" (steadfastly managing our own affairs well). According to a report released by Huawei in April this year, the company's R&D expenditure in 2024 reached 179.7 billion yuan, a year-on-year increase of 9.1%, accounting for 20.8% of its sales revenue. Data from the National Bureau of Statistics show that China's total R&D expenditure in 2024 exceeded 3.6 trillion yuan, reaching 3.613 trillion yuan, an 8.3% increase compared to the previous year, maintaining its position as the second-highest in the world. China's R&D intensity reached 2.68%, ranking 12th among major global economies, surpassing the European Union's average of 2.11% and approaching the OECD average of 2.73%. The Global Innovation Index 2024 report, recently released by the World Intellectual Property Organization, indicates that China's global innovation ranking rose by one place to 11th, making it one of the economies with the fastest-growing innovation capacity over the past decade.

Many Western media outlets, including Reuters and Bloomberg, have placed their focus on this interview within the context of China-U.S. competition and the ongoing economic and trade consultations between the two countries. While such a perspective is not surprising, it somewhat narrows the logic of China's development. Looking solely at the recent achievements of Chinese enterprises—from DeepSeek to Xiaomi's Xuanjie chip and Huawei's "pure" HarmonyOS computer—whether in breakthroughs in key technologies or cluster-style innovations across multiple fields, they ultimately reflect the combined effect of national strategy and market principles. This synergy makes social operations more efficient, industries more dynamic, and people's lives more convenient. This is determined by China's national conditions and system. As Ren Zhengfei said, "One of the goals of socialism is to develop society," which encapsulates this straightforward logic. It is also the source of China's resilience and confidence in addressing various risks and challenges.
